author: LJBC
body:
Personally I don't believe any doctor should be prescribing Ozempic for weight loss.  They should stick to Wegovy, which is the same drug, but specifically sold for weight loss.  Many,  many diabetics are unable to get their Ozempic, approved only for type 2 diabetes,  because so many are using it for weight loss.   This drug has saved me! I was able to get off of insulin and drastically lower my A1C. Now,  I have to worry if I'm able to even get it. This last month I had to drive over an hour away to get it,  and I live in a major metropolitan area.   I got the last of what the store had and none of the pharmacies could get more due to manufacturer shortage.. all due to the off label use of this diabetes drug for weight loss. 
Please wait for Wegovy and leave the Ozempic for the diabetics.

author: [deleted]
body: Hey just a tip, some pharmacies will stock "hidden" Ozempic specifically for people with diabetes. Let your pharmacy know you have diabetes and they might just magically find a pen for you!

author: Alices-Mouse
body: Thank you for saying this!!  I just got spanked for saying the same thing on the ozempic page!  If they limited the people they can prescribe it to, for diabetic use  maybe the supply issues would be better.  Instead of the media touting it as a miracle weight loss drug…

author: Urgash
body:
Yeah i've just left that page too, they're full of copium.

Now even just saying the drug was made for Diabetes and they take down your post saying it "pits diabetics against non diabetics".

author: PAR0824
body:
Hi there, OP! I have relatively similar stats to you..I'm 27F with a starting BMI of almost 33.  I am 5'5" and my highest weight was 196 pounds back in May of this year, when I started to see a weight management doctor. She also recommend that I try a weight loss medication, more specifically Ozempic (wanted to prescribe me Wegovy, but there is even more of a shortage of that medication apparently). I also am not diabetic or prediabetic, and my fasting glucose is always normal and I have an A1C of 4.7 the last time it was checked. I have been on Ozempic for five months now, and have not had any major side effects, besides the occasional slight headache and very minor bouts of nausea. It's absolutely nothing that I can't tolerate, and I don't notice it much anymore, if at all. This morning I weighed in at 157 pounds, which is an all time low for me- almost 40 pounds down in exactly five months. I have a relatively sedentary lifestyle too, doing a few activities here and there but really have only been to the gym one time since beginning Ozempic. My point in saying that is, I have definitely realized that you don't have to incorporate exercise into losing weight, as it's mainly diet and calorie deficits that truly help. Being on Ozempic makes me feel satiated faster and much longer than before. I definitely have less urges and cravings for unhealthy food, and when I eat too much now I actually get nauseated and turned off by food if that makes sense. For me personally, Ozempic has been an absolute lifesaver and the best medication I have ever been on. Thankfully my insurance (somehow!?) covers it too, and I only pay $25 for a month's supply. I have my next weight management appointment in a month, and I am so excited to update my doctor of my progress and hopefully I can continue to use Ozempic for weight loss until I reach my weight goal, since I'm so close!

Anyways, my point being..I honestly can't recommend Ozempic enough, especially if you have a doctor willing to prescribe it to you with no other underlying health conditions besides being overweight and especially if your insurance covers it! If you have any other questions at all, let me know. I would be happy to answer them! Good luck with your weight loss journey, OP..all the best! :)

author: [deleted]
body: Thank you! This is great to hear!

author: [deleted]
body:
Can I ask how your first few weeks went with weight loss? I also have a sedentary job and I can’t always get outside every day. I had my first dose of Ozempic last week and lost three pounds no problem, but then two pounds came back today after my second dose two nights ago. 

I did my first dose in the stomach fat and then second was thigh. I don’t remotely feel any appetite effects from the thigh shot.

author: Mastgoboom
body: Wegovy is the same drug, FdA approved purely for weight loss. There's also Mounjaro which I don't think is covered by any insurance yet, so they have a copay card thing

author: [deleted]
body: [deleted]

author: [deleted]
body: Oh, geez, that's completely out of my price range. If it ends up being the same for me, that answers that question!

author: foxensfancy
body:
I was on samples of a similar medication, same class, but a daily instead of a weekly. 

Every time I scaled up the dose, the GI side effects would come back, but each week it was a little less than the week before, until after about a month it was really just some occasional gas.

I also couldnt get insurance to cover it, even with promising initial results. 1500/month give or take was more than I could out of pocket.

author: [deleted]
body: Most doctors will recommend diet and exercise first, I’m surprised your doctor recommended weight loss medication so early! From a cost perspective I’d go with diet and exercise first and if that isn’t working after a few months then follow up with your doctor. However those medications are incredible for weight loss

author: [deleted]
body: I think the reason he recommended it is that I'm planning to have a surgery soon (early 2023) that it's recommended people be close to their ideal weight in order to have. I'd like to lose a lot of weight and it's not likely I'll be near where I want to be by the time of the surgery, but I can't put the surgery off because my 26th birthday is approaching and don't have much time left on my parents' insurance. I also mentioned that I'm already dieting, and planning to significantly increase my exercise in a few weeks when I'm medically cleared to do so (I'm recovering from a broken ankle-- it's been quite a year, medically speaking).

author: [deleted]
body: Gotcha, yeah sounds like a lot going on! Sorry to hear about all that, can completely understand why you’d want to expedite. I’m not sure how rapidly those medications tend to work, did your physician provide you with that info? I had a higher BMI than you like 2.5 months ago and have shed 30 pounds with dieting and a pretty intense exercise regimen so from my perspective it’s doable without spending a ton of money on meds. but I’m in my last year of medical school so I have a ton of free time on my hands to make it happen which I recognize not everyone does. Good luck with whatever you decide! You’re gonna do great 💪🏻

author: [deleted]
body: It's really inspiring to hear you've been able to lose that much weight in that amount of time! I'd need to confirm, but I'm guessing insurance won't cover the medication if I don't have diabetes, and I just can't afford it out of pocket, so I'll have to be really serious about my diet and exercise.

author: SpecialFuzzy1922
body: Try discount cards like good rx and stuff, I was prescribed a diet pill (phentermine) that was not covered by my insurance but still only paid like $15 for it with the discount cards. I use CVS and they actually just applied the discounts with out me asking even tho I brought the coupon🤷‍♀️

author: [deleted]
body: Thank you, I would not have thought to do this!!

author: WiseTomorrow8897
body: Go to a doctor that is ABOM certified. Also check your insurance to see if they will cover weightloss meds. Some people have success getting other GLP1 meds from Canada pharmacies cheaper if their insurance doesn’t cover. (Saxenda)

author: [deleted]
body: You absolutely have to change habits or it comes back.

author: Daw_dling
body: I’m curious how you maintain the loss once you hit your goal weight? Like if you stop the meds doesn’t the weight come back? I’m on diet and exercise only for right now but my doc mentioned meds as an option if that doesn’t work (PCOS can make weight loss a lot harder)

author: [deleted]
body: Youll do great- i read all the effects and was scared to death. The longer ive been on it the better i feel. It was definitely not great at first GI wise but figured out what my body could handle and slowed the tapering up.

author: dmanco
body: My own weight loss doctor won’t prescribe it. Pre-diabetes with history of diabetes and weight related health issues and he’s adamant. Meanwhile my already small sister in law in Illinois was prescribed it with no diabetes, for cosmetic reasons alone basically. I’d love to try it but for now I will continue counting calories, exercising and trudging along.

author: Street-Doctor6096
body: Hi OP, any update on how you are doing with the drug?

author: [deleted]
body: Super well!

author: jellysm0m
body:
I started seeing the weight loss doctor last February (23). I was at a BMI of 40+. 

I am 49 (next week) and female. I am also 5ft, 1in. The weight is killing me. 

I have tried keto (with success but gained all back plus more when we stopped), WW, NOOM, Better Body, etc. 

Currently, on strict keto and I've lost 10 lbs. However, I know I won't be able to sustain my life on this diet. I just need some of the weight off to make it easier to start walking further/longer. 

When I went to the wl Dr, she almost immediately suggested surgery. With my BMI so high (I don't have blood pressure issues besides it being LOW, and I don't have diabetes or pre-diabetes. My (good and bad) cholesterol is "good") However, I have fibromyalgia. She said that she has had other patients with it, and she has been told/seen evidence of it being almost impossible to lose the large amount of weight with the chronic pain. She also prescribed phentermine.

Taking the meds and following the prescribed diet, I lost 5 lbs and gained 2.

I didn't love the idea of surgery. 

Work got busy, and I had to cancel my follow-up appointments. 

Now, it's been a year already. Not on the phentermine anymore. Since February,  I have gained about 13 lbs and now have lost 10.

I was able to get to my regular doctor in August. I asked him about Wegovy. He didn't hesitate a bit. Prescribed it for me. 

My insurance would not cover it for weight loss. I can't afford to spend $800-1100/month plus my other meds! 
When I go back, I may be looking into the surgery.

Has anyone else had the issue with insurance? I've heard that they won't because you basically have to stay on it for the rest of your life??

Thanks!
